question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump maintains a strong base within the Republican Party, while Joe Biden holds steady with Democratic voters. FiveThirtyEight's national polling averages have shown Trump to be competitive, although not decisively ahead of Biden. Several factors could influence the polling numbers leading up to July 15, 2024, including economic conditions, policy decisions, international events, and public perception of each candidate's performance. Additionally, voter turnout and any unforeseen political developments could impact the margin of lead. Given these variables and the inherent uncertainty in election forecasting, there is a reasonable likelihood that Trump's lead over Biden falls within the 2 to 3-point range on the specified date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes before the end of July 2024, and (2) Trump's lead over Biden be less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
(1) Joe Biden must appear in an in-person interview for at least 45 minutes before the end of July 2024. The interview must be on camera, and can include appearances on a podcast, late night show, or a show like 60 minutes, but there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person. Press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc., do not count. If no qualifying interview is released before the end of July, this condition is not met. 

(2) Trump's lead over Biden must be either less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates Biden is leading. The value will be checked on the chart for July 15, 2024, accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. 

Both conditions must be satisfied for the overall question to resolve YES.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Condition (1) requires President Joe Biden to participate in an in-person, on-camera interview lasting at least 45 minutes before the end of July 2024. Given the precedent of sitting presidents regularly engaging in such interviews with major media outlets, it is highly likely that President Biden will fulfill this requirement. These interviews are standard practice for presidential candidates and incumbents to communicate their policies and respond to public concerns.

Condition (2) involves the national polling average from FiveThirtyEight (538) on July 15, 2024, indicating that former President Donald Trump’s lead over Biden is either less than or equal to 2 percentage points or greater than 3 percentage points. Considering the volatile nature of political polling and the typical fluctuations in the months leading up to a presidential election, it is plausible that Trump's lead could fall within these specified ranges on that specific date.

Both conditions are independent of each other, and given the high likelihood of Condition (1) being met and a reasonable probability for Condition (2) based on typical polling variations, the combined probability that both conditions will be satisfied is high.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average? (b) Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(b) The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of July 5, 2024, Donald Trump leads Joe Biden by 2.4 percentage points in FiveThirtyEight's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election. Assuming that the polling trend remains relatively stable leading up to July 15, it is highly likely that Trump's lead will remain greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 points on that date, satisfying condition (a). Regarding condition (b), Joe Biden has had limited qualifying in-person interviews in recent months, with none exceeding 30 minutes since April. While it is possible that Biden could participate in another 45+ minute in-person interview before the end of July, the likelihood appears lower based on past activity. However, since the question resolves to YES if either (a) or (b) occurs and (a) is highly probable, the overall probability that either condition will be met is very high.

question.title: Will the Orlando Magic win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Orlando Magic are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Orlando Magic have historically been a mid-tier team in the NBA and have not secured an NBA championship in recent decades. As of October 2023, there's no significant indication of a major roster overhaul or the acquisition of superstar talent that could propel them to championship status in the 2024 season. Additionally, the competition in the NBA is fierce, with several established teams consistently performing at a high level. While upsets are always possible in sports, the likelihood of the Orlando Magic winning the 2024 NBA Finals remains low based on current team dynamics and performance trends.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals and the Orlando Magic not win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/): (a) The New York Knicks are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals. (b) The Orlando Magic are not crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals. It resolves as **No** if either the New York Knicks do not win the Finals or the Orlando Magic win the Finals.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the New York Knicks have shown some improvement but are not typically considered among the top contenders for the NBA Finals. Their roster has potential, but they face strong competition from more established teams with higher championship odds. On the other hand, the Orlando Magic have been rebuilding and generally occupy a lower position in the league standings, making their chances of winning the Finals quite slim. Therefore, the likelihood that the Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals while the Magic do not is low.

question.title: Will either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** if neither team wins and they are both eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Both the Orlando Magic and the New York Knicks have shown varying degrees of potential in recent seasons, but neither team has been consistently positioned as a top contender for the NBA Finals. The Orlando Magic, while having a young and developing roster, lack the star power and depth typically required to secure a championship. Similarly, the New York Knicks have made strides in team performance and management but have not yet broken into the elite tier of NBA teams that frequently compete for the title. Additionally, the competition in the NBA is highly competitive, with several established franchises boasting strong rosters, experienced coaching staff, and a history of success. Given these factors, the probability that either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks will win the 2024 NBA Finals is relatively low.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the International Criminal Court (ICC) does not have jurisdiction over Israel since Israel is not a party to the Rome Statute, the treaty that established the ICC. Historically, the ICC has focused its investigations on regions and conflicts where it has clear jurisdiction and cooperation from local governments. While the ICC has shown interest in investigating potential war crimes and violations in various parts of the world, initiating proceedings against high-ranking officials of a non-member state like Israel would require substantial legal and diplomatic shifts. Additionally, there have been no significant developments or indications suggesting that the ICC is preparing to issue arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders—Benjamin Netanyahu, Yoav Gallant, or Herzi Halevi—by the specified resolution date of July 1, 2024. Given these factors, it is unlikely that the ICC will take such action within the given timeframe.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) A terrorist act occurs in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics (2) Before July 1, 2024, the ICC does not issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
(1) The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

(2) This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) does not issue a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of a terrorist attack occurring in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics is relatively low due to the extensive security measures typically implemented for such large-scale international events. While the risk cannot be entirely eliminated, historical data suggests that the probability remains minimal. Regarding the second condition, as of the latest information up to October 2023, there have been no indications or ongoing proceedings by the International Criminal Court (ICC) to issue arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders (Benjamin Netanyahu, Yoav Gallant, Herzi Halevi). Given the absence of such developments and the typically lengthy processes involved in ICC actions, it is reasonable to assess that the ICC is unlikely to issue arrest warrants for these individuals before July 1, 2024. Combining these assessments, the probability that both conditions occur is quite low.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) the ICC issues arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders by July 1, 2024, (b) a terrorist act occurs in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a warrant of arrest for any of the following Israeli cabinet members: Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister), Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister), Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff). It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

(b) The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in Metropolitan France injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen. An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that either (a) the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders by July 1, 2024, or (b) a terrorist act occurs in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics, we must evaluate each scenario separately and then consider their combined likelihood.

(a) **ICC Issuing Arrest Warrants for Israeli Leaders:** The ICC operates based on principles of international law and jurisdiction. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no formal moves or indications that the ICC is set to issue arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders. Such actions typically require substantial evidence of international crimes, extensive legal processes, and political considerations. Given the complexities involved and the absence of public indications pointing toward this outcome, the probability of the ICC issuing such warrants by July 1, 2024, appears low.

(b) **Terrorist Act in Metropolitan France During the 2024 Summer Olympics:** Major international events like the Summer Olympics are high-profile targets for potential terrorist activities due to the global attention and large gatherings. While host countries implement extensive security measures to mitigate such risks, the unpredictable nature of terrorism makes it difficult to assign a definitive probability. Historical data shows that while the likelihood of an attack doesn't increase to certainty, the potential for such incidents remains present, albeit generally low due to preventive efforts.

Considering both scenarios: - The probability of (a) occurring is low. - The probability of (b) occurring, while also low, is influenced by the high-security environment but cannot be ruled out entirely.

Assuming these events are independent, the combined probability of either event occurring would be slightly higher than each individual probability but still remains low overall.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, predicting specific polling outcomes for July 15, 2024, involves considerable uncertainty due to the dynamic nature of political campaigns, voter sentiment, unforeseen events, and changes in public opinion. Historically, polling leads can fluctuate significantly as elections approach, influenced by factors such as economic conditions, international events, candidate performances in debates, and media coverage. Additionally, the margin specified—greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 percentage points—represents a relatively narrow range that can be affected by minor shifts in voter preferences. Given these variables and the inherent unpredictability of electoral politics, assigning a precise probability is challenging. However, considering the uncertainties and the typical variability in polling data as elections near, it's plausible to estimate a moderate probability for this scenario.

question.title: Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and will Trump's lead over Biden be less than or equal to 3 or greater than 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is less than or equal to 3 or greater than 4 on July 15, 2024, according to the chart accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. 

For condition (a), it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

For condition (b), a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, a value of 2.4 means Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden. The question will resolve as **Yes** if Trump's lead is <= 3 or > 4 on the specified date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the latest information up to October 2023, Chris Christie has not announced a campaign for the 2024 Republican nomination, and there is no significant indication that he will secure the nomination. Donald Trump remains the prominent figure within the Republican Party with substantial support, making it unlikely that Christie would overcome Trump's influence to become the nominee. Additionally, predicting the specific polling dynamics between Trump and Biden on July 15, 2024, is highly uncertain. However, since both conditions (Christie securing the nomination and the specified polling scenario) need to be met for the question to resolve as "Yes," the combined probability of both occurring is very low.

question.title: Will either Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, or Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) is greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, as reported on the chart when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. (b) Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that either Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in FiveThirtyEight's national polling average is greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, or that Chris Christie becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to assess both scenarios independently and then consider their combined probability.

1. Trump's Polling Lead:
As of October 2023, Donald Trump remains a prominent figure in the Republican Party with substantial support from his base. Joe Biden, as the incumbent president, has his own set of approval ratings. FiveThirtyEight aggregates various polls to provide a national average. Predicting the exact polling numbers for July 2024 involves uncertainty due to factors like campaign developments, policy decisions, economic conditions, and unforeseen events. Historically, polling leads can fluctuate significantly in the months leading up to an election. A lead between 3 and 4 points is within a competitive range and plausible, especially if both candidates maintain steady support without major shifts.

2. Chris Christie as the Republican Nominee:
Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey, ran for the Republican nomination in 2016 but did not secure it. As of 2023, there is limited indication that Christie is actively seeking the 2024 nomination or has significant support within the Republican Party to mount a competitive primary campaign against frontrunners like Donald Trump. The Republican field for 2024 seems to be more prominently featuring other candidates with higher visibility and support.

Combined Probability:
Given that the first scenario (Trump's polling lead) is plausible and the second scenario (Chris Christie winning the nomination) is highly unlikely based on current political dynamics, the probability that at least one of these events occurs (i.e., a logical OR) is dominated by the likelihood of the first event.

question.title: Will Malta qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Malta participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If they do not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Malta has a history of fluctuating performances in the Eurovision Song Contest, with periods of both successful qualifications and non-qualifications for the Grand Final. In recent years leading up to 2023, Malta has qualified for the Grand Final approximately half of the time. Factors that influence their chances include the quality and appeal of their selected entry, staging, and the competitiveness of their semi-final group. Additionally, changes in voting patterns and the overall strength of entries from other participating countries can impact Malta's likelihood of qualifying. Given these considerations and the inherent unpredictability of the competition, it is reasonable to estimate a moderate probability of Malta qualifying for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final.

question.title: Will both of the following occur in Eurovision 2024: (a) Slovenia qualifies for the Grand Final, and (b) Malta fails to qualify for the Grand Final?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Slovenia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, and (b) Malta either does not participate in a Semi-final or is not officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If either condition is not met, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that both Slovenia qualifies for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final and Malta fails to qualify, we can analyze historical performance trends and recent developments up to October 2023.

**Slovenia's Qualification History:**
Slovenia has participated in Eurovision since 1993 and has qualified for the Grand Final numerous times, though not consistently every year. In recent years, Slovenia has shown varied performance, with some strong showings and a few non-qualifications. Their chances often depend on factors such as song quality, staging, and geopolitical voting patterns.

**Malta's Qualification History:**
Malta has a relatively strong track record in Eurovision, frequently qualifying for the Grand Final. They have achieved several top 10 finishes and are generally perceived as a consistent performer with broad appeal. Malta's entries often feature standout performances that resonate well with both juries and the public.

**Current Factors Influencing 2024:**
As of October 2023, both countries are likely preparing their entries with an emphasis on maximizing their strengths. Slovenia may be aiming for a more impactful staging or a memorable song to improve their qualification odds. Malta, maintaining its reputation, would likely continue to send entries that have a high likelihood of qualifying.

**Combined Probability:**
The probability that Slovenia qualifies while Malta fails to qualify involves two independent events based on their historical performances and current trajectories. Given Slovenia's moderate qualification rate and Malta's stronger consistency in qualifying, the likelihood of both events occurring simultaneously is relatively low.

question.title: Will either Malta or Slovenia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Malta or Slovenia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If neither qualifies, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that either Malta or Slovenia will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we can consider their historical performance, the strength of their selected entries, and the overall competition landscape. Historically, both Malta and Slovenia have had varying degrees of success in Eurovision. Malta has a strong fan base and has qualified for the final multiple times in recent years, often performing well with captivating performances. Slovenia, on the other hand, has struggled more frequently to qualify for the final, though there have been exceptions. The quality and appeal of the 2024 entries from both countries will play a crucial role; if Malta selects a particularly strong or popular entry, their chances improve. Additionally, the number of participating countries and the voting dynamics each year can influence qualification outcomes. Taking these factors into account, it is plausible that at least one of the two countries could secure a spot in the Grand Final.

question.body:

1. [Credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report that Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

To estimate the probability that both events (a) Donald Trump testifies at the hush money trial and (b) Will Hurd is not the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election) occur by August 1, 2024, we need to assess each event individually and then consider their conjunction.

(a) **Donald Trump Testifying at the Hush Money Trial**: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump faces legal challenges, including investigations related to hush money payments. Whether he will testify depends on various factors, including legal strategies, court orders, and his own decisions. (b) **Will Hurd Not Being the Republican Nominee**: Will Hurd, a former congressman, has shown interest in running for office but has not been a leading contender for the Republican nomination. Assuming that these two events are somewhat independent, the probability that both occur is the product of their individual probabilities.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that the question resolves as **Yes**, we need to assess the likelihood of at least one of the following events occurring by August 1, 2024:

(a) **Will Hurd be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?**
   - **Current Political Landscape:** As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump remains a prominent figure within the Republican Party and has shown interest in running for the presidency again. His strong influence and established base make him a leading contender for the nomination.
   - **Competitive Field:** While there are other potential Republican candidates, Hurd would face significant challenges in securing the nomination over a potentially dominant figure like Trump, unless there are substantial shifts in the political dynamics or unexpected events.

(b) **Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?**
   - **Legal Proceedings:** Given the ongoing nature of legal investigations and trials involving Trump, it is plausible that he may be required to testify, either voluntarily or through legal summons.
   - **Public Statements:** Trump has made statements regarding his commitment to defending himself in legal matters, which may include testifying to address the charges or allegations.

Considering both scenarios, while Hurd becoming the nominee is uncertain and possibly less likely given the current political landscape, Trump's potential testimony in the hush money trial is more probable. Therefore, the likelihood of at least one of these events occurring by the resolution date is high.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?
question.body:
Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/24034/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if before August 1, 2024, one of these four events happens, according to official statements or credible reports:

The Philippines expels at least one diplomat representing the People's Republic of China (PRC).

The Philippines recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the PRC.

The PRC expels at least one diplomat representing the Philippines.

The PRC recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the Philippines.

If there are no such reports before that date, then this resolves as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

question.title: Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China between June 1, 2024, and August 1, 2024?
question.body:

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the European Parliament is primarily dominated by larger political groups such as the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). Historically, these groups have held the most seats in previous European Parliamentary elections, including the 2019 elections. The Greens–European Free Alliance (Greens–EFA) has been growing in influence and representation, benefiting from increasing public concern over environmental issues and climate change. However, surpassing the traditional larger groups to become the largest faction would require significant shifts in voter behavior and political alliances across multiple member states. While there is a trend of rising support for green politics in various European countries, the fragmentation of the vote and the presence of other emerging parties make it challenging for Greens–EFA to secure the most seats outright. Therefore, although their influence is increasing, it remains unlikely that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats in the European Parliament following the 2024 elections.

question.title: Will both of the following occur after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections: (a) GUE/NGL holds the most seats, and (b) Greens–EFA does not hold the most seats?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met after the 2024 European Parliament elections: (a) GUE/NGL holds the most seats, and (b) Greens–EFA does not hold the most seats. It will resolve as **No** if either GUE/NGL does not hold the most seats or Greens–EFA holds the most seats.

For GUE/NGL, the resolution is based on whether they hold the most seats, with ties resulting in a **Yes** outcome.

For Greens–EFA, the resolution is based on whether they do not hold the most seats, with ties resulting in a **No** outcome.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

The largest groups typically include the European People's Party (EPP), the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), and Renew Europe. Given the historical performance and current standings, it is highly unlikely that GUE/NGL will secure the most seats in the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. Additionally, the Greens–European Free Alliance (Greens–EFA) is also not among the largest groups and is unlikely to hold the most seats. However, the primary condition for a "Yes" resolution hinges on GUE/NGL holding the most seats, which is improbable. Therefore, the probability that both conditions (a) GUE/NGL holds the most seats and (b) Greens–EFA does not hold the most seats are met is very low.

question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: In the Olympics, tennis players have the opportunity to compete in multiple events, including singles, doubles, and mixed doubles. Historically, there have been instances where athletes have secured multiple medals by performing well across different categories. For example, a top-ranked singles player might also excel in the doubles or mixed doubles events, increasing the likelihood of winning more than one medal. Additionally, the Olympics often attract the best talent from around the world, raising the competitive standards and the potential for exceptional performances. Considering the structure of Olympic tennis events and past occurrences, it is plausible that at least one athlete could win multiple medals in the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Will both of the following occur at the 2024 Olympics: (a) No nation wins more than one women's team sport (b) No athlete wins more than one medal for tennis?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

(a) Women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in these eight team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. This means no single NOC wins more than one of these events.

(b) No athlete wins more than one medal for tennis.

If both conditions are met, the question resolves as **Yes**. If either condition is not met, the question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: At the 2024 Paris Olympics, it is unlikely that eight different National Olympic Committees (NOCs) will each win gold in the eight women's team sports listed. Historically, certain countries such as the United States, China, and various European nations tend to dominate multiple team sports, making it probable that some NOCs will secure more than one gold medal across these events. For example, the USA is strong in basketball, volleyball, and water polo, increasing the chances of multiple golds from a single NOC. Additionally, while the likelihood of no athlete winning more than one medal in tennis (condition b) is fairly reasonable, the combination of both conditions being met simultaneously is improbable. Therefore, the probability that both conditions (a) and (b) occur at the 2024 Olympics is low.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the 2024 Paris Olympics: (a) An athlete wins more than one medal for tennis, (b) The same nation wins more than one women's team sport?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

(b) The same National Olympic Committee (NOC) wins gold in more than one of the following women's team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics:
- association football
- 3×3 basketball
- 5×5 basketball
- field hockey
- handball
- rugby sevens
- volleyball
- water polo.

The question resolves as **No** if women's teams representing eight different NOCs win gold in these eight team sports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: At the Olympic level, it's plausible for an athlete to compete in multiple tennis events, such as singles and doubles, increasing the likelihood of winning more than one medal. Additionally, powerhouse nations like the United States, China, and others often excel in multiple women's team sports. For example, the USA typically performs strongly in sports like basketball, volleyball, and soccer. Given the depth of talent and resources these countries invest in their sports programs, it's likely that one nation will secure multiple golds across different women's team events.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

While his personal appeal and policy positions resonate with a segment of the Republican base, capturing the nomination in a crowded and competitive field presents significant challenges.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Greens–EFA holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections (b) Trump's lead over Biden is ≤ 2 or > 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, this sub-question will resolve as **Yes**. This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) is less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
(a) The Greens–EFA group currently holds a smaller proportion of seats in the European Parliament compared to larger groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). Historically, the EPP and S&D have been the dominant groups, and there is no significant trend suggesting that the Greens–EFA will surpass them in the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. Achieving the most seats would require a substantial and unprecedented surge in support for the Greens–EFA, which appears highly unlikely based on current political landscapes and past election results.

(b) Regarding the polling between Trump and Biden on July 15, 2024, without specific data from that date, it's challenging to predict the exact polling numbers. However, historical polling trends suggest that major party candidates typically have a spread that avoids narrow margins like a lead between 2 and 3 points. Given the volatility of political campaigns and polling dynamics, it's reasonable to assume that Trump's lead would fall outside the narrow 2-3 point range, either being less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 points.

Since part (a) is highly unlikely to resolve as **Yes**, the combined probability that both (a) and (b) occur is very low.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**. This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that either (a) Trump's lead over Biden is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to FiveThirtyEight's national polling average, or (b) the Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we consider each scenario separately.

(a) **Trump's Polling Lead**: As of the latest data up to October 2023, Joe Biden holds the incumbency advantage, and historical polling trends suggest that incumbent presidents generally maintain a stable or increasing lead as the election approaches, barring significant political upheaval or scandals. Additionally, polling averages from sources like FiveThirtyEight tend to favor incumbents. While Trump remains a strong contender within the Republican Party, a lead of 2 to 3 points over Biden by mid-July 2024 seems unlikely based on current trends.

(b) **Greens–EFA in European Parliament**: The Greens–European Free Alliance (Greens–EFA) have been a growing force in European politics, focusing on environmental and progressive issues. However, historically, major political groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) have held the largest number of seats in the European Parliament. While the Greens–EFA are gaining traction, overtaking these established groups in the 2024 elections would require a significant and possibly unprecedented shift in voter sentiment across multiple member states.

Assuming the independence of both events, the probability that either occurs is the sum of their individual probabilities minus the probability that both occur. Given the factors above, both events individually have low probabilities, and the overlap is negligible.

For the Democratic Party to have a brokered convention in 2024, no single candidate would need to secure a majority of delegates through the primary elections. Historically, brokered conventions are rare and typically occur only when there's significant division within the party or an exceptionally close primary race. Given the current political landscape and the presence of strong candidates likely to unify the party, a brokered Democratic convention seems unlikely. 

Regarding Francis Suarez, he is one of several candidates vying for the Republican nomination. While he has gained some attention, the Republican field includes established figures who may have broader support within the party. The outcome of the Republican nomination process will depend on various factors, including campaign strategies, voter preferences, and potential endorsements. It is plausible that Suarez may not secure the nomination if other candidates consolidate support.

The probability that both a brokered Democratic convention occurs and Suarez does not become the Republican nominee involves two relatively independent events. Given the low likelihood of a brokered Democratic convention and the moderate uncertainty surrounding Suarez's nomination prospects, the combined probability is relatively low.

While both parties aim to consolidate the right-wing vote, significant ideological differences exist between them. Les Républicains positions themselves as center-right, whereas the National Rally is further to the right, often associated with more nationalist and populist policies. There have been no credible reports or indications of ongoing negotiations or discussions toward forming a political alliance for the 2024 French legislative election. Additionally, both parties have strong individual leadership and distinct voter bases, which can make forming a coalition challenging. Given these factors and the lack of public or insider information suggesting imminent collaboration, it is unlikely that these two parties will form an electoral alliance by the resolution date.

(b) No electoral alliance or coalition agreement is officially announced between the Republicans Party (Les Républicains) and National Rally (Rassemblement National) for the 2024 French legislative election before June 30, 2024, according to credible sources. The "Together" coalition, led by Emmanuel Macron's La République En Marche! (LREM) party, has been seeking to consolidate support ahead of the 2024 legislative elections. Macron's administration has faced challenges, including economic issues and public dissatisfaction, which could influence coalition dynamics by July 2024.

The Republicans (Les Républicains) have traditionally been one of France's major center-right parties. However, in recent years, they have experienced internal divisions and declining support, which might impede their ability to form strong alliances. On the other hand, the National Rally (Rassemblement National), led by Marine Le Pen, has been steadily increasing its influence, positioning itself as a major force in French politics. An alliance between Les Républicains and the National Rally would represent a significant shift to the right, but past cooperation has been minimal due to ideological differences and strategic considerations.

Given these factors:

(a) The likelihood of the Prime Minister belonging to the Together coalition depends on the coalition's ability to maintain unity and voter support amidst economic and social challenges. If the coalition successfully addresses key issues and mitigates internal conflicts, it's plausible they could retain the Prime Minister position by July 30, 2024.

(b) The possibility of the Republicans not forming an alliance with the National Rally hinges on the parties' strategic interests and ideological compatibility. Considering their historical reluctance to collaborate and potential voter base overlaps that might lead to electoral competition rather than cooperation, it's plausible that no official alliance would be formed by the specified date.

Considering the current political trends and potential developments leading up to mid-2024, there is a reasonable probability that both conditions could be met simultaneously.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context indicates that House Democrats are actively organizing to oppose the DNC's plan to seal President Biden's nomination early. A drafted letter has been circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman, suggesting that there is momentum behind this effort. While Rep. Huffman declined to confirm the letter's existence, the fact that multiple Democrats are involved in organizing and discussing this action increases the likelihood of garnering significant support. Typically, mobilizing 20 members in the House or Senate is achievable, especially when there is a coordinated effort and clear opposition within the party. Considering these factors, it is reasonably probable that at least 20 Democrats will sign the public letter by the specified deadline.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024 (b) Fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
(a) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024: This question resolves as Yes if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as No.

(b) Fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early: This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by fewer than 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. Multiple such letters with a combined total of fewer than 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that both (a) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024 and (b) fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early, we need to evaluate each condition and their interdependence.

Condition (a): Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024.
A brokered convention occurs when no single candidate secures a majority of delegates before the convention, necessitating multiple rounds of voting to select the nominee. Historically, the Democratic Party has streamlined its nomination process to prevent brokered conventions, especially when an incumbent or clear front-runner is present. Given that Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has substantial support within the party, the likelihood of a brokered convention is low.

Condition (b): Fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.
The push for virtual nominations aims to ensure safety and accessibility, especially in the context of ongoing public health considerations. While there might be some opposition, the number of dissenting House or Senate Democrats publicly opposing this plan is likely to be limited. The organizational structures and party cohesion typically discourage widespread public dissent, suggesting that fewer than 20 lawmakers would take such a stance.

Joint Probability Assessment:
Condition (a) is highly unlikely given the current political landscape and party structures. Even though Condition (b) is probable, the overall probability that both conditions occur simultaneously is driven primarily by the improbability of Condition (a).

question.title: Will either at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early, or will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if either of the following conditions are met: (a) A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st, 2024. Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient. (b) The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If neither condition is met, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: President Biden maintains strong support within the Democratic Party, and there has been no significant movement indicating widespread opposition to his early virtual nomination. Securing signatures from at least 20 House or Senate Democrats to publicly oppose his nomination would require a substantial and coordinated effort, which currently seems unlikely given the party's general cohesiveness around his leadership. Additionally, the Democratic Party has shown a tendency to rally behind their nominee rather than pursue a brokered convention, especially in the case of an incumbent president seeking renomination. Brokered conventions are rare and typically occur only when there is significant division within the party, which does not appear to be the case at this time. Therefore, the probability that either at least 20 Democrats will sign a public opposition letter or that the party will have a brokered convention in 2024 is low.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The same nation wins more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics (b) The 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is a Man?
question.body:
(a) The question about the 2024 Olympics resolves as Yes if any National Olympic Committee (NOC) wins gold in at least two of the eight women's team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, it resolves as No. 

(b) The question about the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee resolves as Yes if the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election. It resolves as No if they select a female presidential nominee.

This combined question resolves as Yes only if both (a) and (b) resolve as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that both (a) the same nation wins more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics and (b) the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is a man, we can evaluate each part separately:

**(a) Same Nation Winning Multiple Women's Team Sports at the 2024 Olympics:**
Historically, certain nations, particularly the United States, have demonstrated dominance across multiple women's team sports such as basketball, volleyball, and soccer. The U.S. has strong infrastructure, funding, and a large talent pool that contribute to their success in these areas. Additionally, other countries like China, the Netherlands, and Australia have shown prowess in multiple team sports, increasing the likelihood that at least one nation will secure multiple gold medals across different women's team events.

**(b) 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee Being a Man:**
As of October 2023, the Democratic primary field includes both male and female candidates. While there has been significant progress in gender representation within the Democratic Party, predicting the nominee's gender involves assessing current political dynamics, candidate popularity, and voter sentiments. Historically, the party has nominated both men and women, but without certainty regarding the primary outcomes, assigning a specific probability is challenging.

**Combined Assessment:**
Given the strong likelihood that at least one nation, particularly the U.S., will win multiple women's team sports at the Olympics, and considering the ongoing and competitive nature of the Democratic primaries with no clear frontrunner, the probability that both (a) and (b) occur simultaneously is influenced primarily by the uncertainty surrounding the nomination process.

question.body:
(a) The question about the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee resolves “yes” if/when the Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election. It resolves “no” if/when the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

(b) The question about the 2024 Olympics resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, it resolves as Yes if the same NOC wins at least two of these events.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
For part (a), the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is highly likely to be Joe Biden, the incumbent president, who is male. As incumbents typically secure re-nomination unless there is significant opposition, and there has been no substantial indication of a strong female challenger within the Democratic Party, the probability of a female nominee is low.

For part (b), the 2024 Olympics feature eight women's team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. The United States traditionally excels in multiple of these sports, particularly in basketball (both 3×3 and 5×5), volleyball, and water polo. Given the USA's strong track record and depth in these disciplines, it is highly probable that the same nation will win more than one of these women's team sports at the 2024 Olympics.

Since part (b) is very likely to resolve as "yes," the overall probability that at least one of the two events occurs is high.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Invoking the 25th Amendment Section 4 to declare President Biden incapacitated would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been no indication of such a move or consensus among key administration officials. The 25th Amendment has never been invoked in this manner, and doing so would involve significant political and constitutional implications. Without any public evidence or credible reports suggesting imminent action to declare President Biden incapacitated, it is highly unlikely that this will occur before August 2024.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President AND (2) Biden is not declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024?
question.body:
(1) This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination.

(2) Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) do not invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and do not cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that both (1) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President and (2) Biden is not declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, we can consider the following factors:

1. **Political Context**: As of July 1, 2024, Joe Biden is the incumbent president. Historically, incumbent presidents who seek re-election typically announce their intentions well in advance. However, unforeseen circumstances such as health issues or political pressures can lead to late announcements or decisions not to run.

2. **Biden's Political Career and Age**: Joe Biden, born in 1942, would be nearing 82 years old by July 2024. While age is a factor, it's not unprecedented for presidents to seek and win re-election at this age (e.g., Ronald Reagan, Donald Trump). Unless there are clear indications of health concerns or waning political support, his decision to run might not be solely based on age.

3. **Health Considerations**: The second condition involves Biden not being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment before August 2024. As of early July, there have been no public indications of significant health issues that would necessitate such a declaration. Biden has maintained a relatively active public schedule, suggesting stability in his health status.

4. **Political Stability**: The absence of major political upheavals or crises that could impact Biden's decision to run or his health status contributes to the likelihood that both conditions remain favorable for both criteria to be met.

Considering these factors, the likelihood that Biden announces he will not seek re-election before July 15, 2024, is relatively low given his incumbency and lack of public health concerns. Additionally, the probability that he is not declared incapacitated before August 2024 is high, given the absence of health-related announcements.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, (b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Declaring a sitting U.S. president incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 is an extremely rare and serious action that requires both the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree that the president is unable to perform the duties of the office. As of now, there is no public indication or movement suggesting that such a declaration against President Biden is imminent. Similarly, for President Biden to announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not seek the Democratic nomination would represent a significant and unprecedented shift, especially given his position as the incumbent and the typical timeline for such announcements. Unless there have been recent developments or statements from Biden or his campaign indicating a withdrawal from the race, both scenarios (a) and (b) appear highly unlikely within the specified time frame.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or another relevant body) to formally declare the President incapacitated. This process is unprecedented and has never been successfully executed in U.S. history. As of the latest available information up to October 2023, there have been no indications of President Biden experiencing such incapacities that would warrant this action. Additionally, political motivations alone are insufficient for such a significant constitutional procedure without clear evidence of incapacity. While a GOP lawmaker has called for Attorney General Merrick Garland to consider invoking the 25th Amendment, actual implementation would require substantial consensus and evidence, which appears highly unlikely in the current political climate. Therefore, the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is exceedingly low.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday, July 19, 2024, and (b) Biden not be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question resolves to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for July 19, 2024. It resolves to “No” if Trump has a higher probability. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, it resolves 50-50. The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast. If no data for July 19 is available by July 22, it resolves according to the nearest previous figures.

(b) This question resolves to YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet do not invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare Biden unable to discharge his duties before August 2024. Biden exiting the office by death, resignation, etc., does not count, nor does Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment. The duration of incapacity does not matter.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
(a) FiveThirtyEight (538) typically projects the incumbent president as the favorite in re-election races, assuming there are no significant shifts in the political landscape or major unforeseen events that drastically alter public opinion. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden holds the position of the incumbent with no immediate signs indicating a loss in favorability. Unless there are major political, economic, or personal events affecting President Biden between October 2023 and July 19, 2024, it is reasonable to expect that 538 would project Biden as the favorite on that date.

(b) The invocation of Section 4 of the 25th Amendment requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to declare the President incapacitated. This is a rare and serious action, typically reserved for situations where the President is unable to perform their duties due to severe illness or other incapacitating conditions. As of the latest information available to me, there are no indications or public information suggesting that President Biden is facing health issues or circumstances that would lead to such a declaration. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that the 25th Amendment would be invoked to declare President Biden incapacitated before August 2024.

Assuming that both events (a) and (b) are independent, the probability that both occur is the product of their individual probabilities. Given that both scenarios are highly likely based on the current information, the combined probability remains very high.

question.title: Will either Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, or will 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves to YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This occurs if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count. (b) FiveThirtyEight projects Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024. This occurs if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that the question resolves to YES, we need to assess the likelihood of either of the two conditions occurring before August 2024.

(a) **Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4**: Historically, the invocation of the 25th Amendment Section 4 is extremely rare and typically requires clear evidence of the President’s inability to perform duties. As of the latest information up to October 2023, there have been no significant indications or movements within the Vice President and Cabinet to consider such an action against President Biden. Unless unforeseen major health issues arise, the probability of this scenario is very low.

(b) **FiveThirtyEight projecting Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024**: FiveThirtyEight’s projections are based on comprehensive polling and statistical models. Given that President Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election, and assuming that he maintains a stable approval rating without significant decline, it is plausible that FiveThirtyEight would project him as a favorite as the election approaches. However, election dynamics can change based on various factors such as economic conditions, political developments, and campaign effectiveness. Therefore, there is a reasonable probability that FiveThirtyEight would project Biden as the favorite by mid-2024.

Since condition (a) is highly unlikely and condition (b) has a moderately high probability, the overall probability that at least one of these conditions occurs is primarily driven by the likelihood of condition (b).

question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:

 - Eric Trump

He remains a dominant figure within the Republican Party with a strong base of support. While other members of the Trump family, such as Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, have been involved in political activities and have considered their own political aspirations, none have formally entered the race for the 2024 nomination.
